content:
In SeparationQuotient.lift, for (f : X → α) (hf : ∀ (x y : X), Inseparable x y → f x = f y) p.liftQ f h is defined as a map such that lift f hf(mk x) = f x, but is this the standard terminology? It feels rather that the RHS is the lift of the LHS.
cf. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lift_(mathematics)

This naming comes from the naming of docs#Quotient.lift. Arguably it should be called Quotient.desc and this is how it is called in the category theory limits API, see e.g. docs#CategoryTheory.Limits.colimit.desc

We discuss this periodically, and have been discussing it at least since 2017. The current terminology is definitely backward compared to mathematics but it is very much entrenched, including in Lean core.
in other words, it is difficult change, I see.
Yoh Tanimoto has marked this topic as resolved.
I don't think it is impossible for Mathlib to change unilaterally however.

Kim Morrison said:

I don't think it is impossible for Mathlib to change unilaterally however.

Isn’t this terminology introduced in core?
Yes, but Mathlib could choose to not name further things lift.
(My take here is that lift is just wrong, and mathematicians have the right words here that unfortunately got scrambled.)
That said, I don't want to make a case for renaming it in Lean; I'm just proposing moving where the seam occurs.
Yoh Tanimoto has marked this topic as unresolved.
I coud start by renaming lift by Inseparable setoid, indeed I have some related PR #18178. What is the mathematically right terminology? desc, or maybe factor?
Yoh Tanimoto has marked this topic as unresolved.
